{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3329479,"name":"Jhoannitta","username":"tokio3000","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/e0b2c6/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-11T01:11:44.067Z","cooked":"

Hello, good night beautiful people
We are in the process of designing the transmission of our robot and we had a big question.
We are debating the positioning of the motor that generates the movement of the pivot of our intake.
In the past regional we decided to fix it to the bellypan, for the next regional we decided to redesign a new transmission and we are deciding where to position the engine this time.
What do you recommend for the design, fix it again to the bellypan or fix it in the air, and if it is in the air, how could we do it?
I attach a photo of the design we have had so far.

TRANSMISION1048×488 159 KB

tokio3000:

for the next regional we decided to redesign a new transmission

Why are you redesigning the transmission?

tokio3000:

fix it again to the bellypan or fix it in the air,

In general, the lower you can move heavy stuff, the better. If you already have design that puts the motors on the bellypan, I wouldn’t change that.

Here’s my suggestion. Keep the motor/planetary attached to the bellypan, unless it’s thinner than the walls of that yellow bar. Past that, here are some suggestions:

image1566×878 134 KB

I’m from her team, at first we decided to use the gears for 3 things:

  • To avoid combined load ratings
  • To the forces where loaded on to the hexagonal shaft with the gears and not into the base shaft of the motor
  • And to put the both sprockets vertically, one on top of the other, 'cause putting the bigger sprocket on top of the base shaft motor makes it to not fit in the frame; and we think it could be better to manage the forces

There is only some knowledge we have, but we would appreciate too much if there is something we are missing or is incorrectly
